- Locally you need . env so the code can read GOOGLE_API_KEY.

+ On GitHub you must exclude . env so the key stays secret.
Those two statements are both true—and perfectly safe—as long as . env is listed in .gitignore.

Quick safety check

1. Open .gitignore (create one if it doesn't exist) and make sure it contains:

© Copy
-env
__pycache__/
.venv/
2. Verify GitHub really doesn’t have .env
bash © Copy

git ls-files | grep .env

Or on GitHub use the file search bar—if . env isn’t listed, you're safe.

Why your API key is still private

+ Git only uploads files that are tracked.

+ Because . env is ignored, it stays on your laptop only.

+ The repo you screenshotted online shows no . env—so the wad never left your machine.
